answer_html: Hence, lightbulb \(A\) has the longer expected lifetime.
answer_latex: Hence, lightbulb $A$ has the longer expected lifetime.
hints_html:
The expected lifetime, or the expected time to failure, is the mean value of the random variable \(t\) (the time to failure).

Recall from (a) and (b) that \(p_A(t) = e^{-t}\) and \(p_B(t) = 2e^{-2t}.\)
hints_latex:
The expected lifetime, or the expected time to failure, is the mean
value of the random variable $t$ (the time to failure).
Recall from (a) and (b) that $p_A(t) = e^{-t}$ and $p_B(t) = 2e^{-2t}.$
hints_raw:
The expected lifetime, or the expected time to failure, is the mean value of the random variable <math>t </math> (the time to failure).
Recall from (a) and (b) that <math>p_A(t) = e^{-t}</math> and <math>p_B(t) = 2e^{-2t}.</math>
question: 5 (d)
sols_html:
The expected lifetime of lightbulb \(A\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \overline t_A= \int_0^\infty t p_A(t)dt= \int_0^\infty t e^{-t} dt\end{aligned}\]

Integrating by parts,

\[\begin{aligned} \overline t_A &= \left[-te^{-t}\right]_0^\infty- \int_0^\infty (- e^{-t}) dt = \int_0^\infty e^{-t}\, dt =\left.-e^{-t}\right|_0^\infty = 1.\end{aligned}\]

The expected lifetime of lightbulb \(B\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \overline t_B= \int_0^\infty t p_B(t)dt= 2\int_0^\infty t e^{-2t} dt \end{aligned}\]

Again, integrating by parts,

\[\begin{aligned} \overline t_B= 2\left[-t\frac{ e^{-2t}}{2} \right]_0^\infty-2\int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-2t} }{(-2)}dt =\int_0^\infty e^{-2t} dt = \left.\frac{e^{-2t}}{-2}\right|_0^\infty =\frac12.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, lightbulb \(A\) has the longer expected lifetime.
sols_raw:
The expected lifetime of lightbulb <math>A </math> is 


<math> \begin{align}
\overline t_A= \int_0^\infty t p_A(t)dt= \int_0^\infty t e^{-t} dt
\end{align}</math>

Integrating by parts, 

<math> \begin{align}
\overline t_A & = \left[-te^{-t}\right]_0^\infty- \int_0^\infty (- e^{-t}) dt = \int_0^\infty e^{-t}\, dt =\left.-e^{-t}\right|_0^\infty = 1.
\end{align}</math>

The expected lifetime of lightbulb <math>B </math> is 

<math> \begin{align}
\overline t_B= \int_0^\infty t p_B(t)dt= 2\int_0^\infty t e^{-2t} dt 
\end{align}</math>

Again, integrating by parts,

<math> \begin{align}
\overline t_B=  2\left[-t\frac{ e^{-2t}}{2} \right]_0^\infty-2\int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-2t} }{(-2)}dt =\int_0^\infty e^{-2t} dt = \left. \frac{e^{-2t}}{-2}\right|_0^\infty =\frac12.
\end{align}</math>

Hence, lightbulb <math>A </math> has the longer expected lifetime.
statement_html:
In a room two different lightbulbs \(A\) and \(B\) are installed. According to the packaging, lightbulb \(A\) fails before time \(t\) with probability \(F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}\) (\(t\) in months). Lightbulb \(B\) has a probability density function for the failure time given by \(p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.\)

Which light bulb has the longer expected lifetime? (i.e. longer average time to failure.) Show your reasoning.
statement_latex:
In a room two different lightbulbs $A$ and $B$ are installed. According
to the packaging, lightbulb $A$ fails before time $t$ with probability
$F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}$ ($t$ in months). Lightbulb $B$ has a probability
density function for the failure time given by $p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.$

Which light bulb has the longer expected lifetime? (i.e. longer average
time to failure.) Show your reasoning.
statement_raw:
In a  room two different lightbulbs <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> are installed. According to the packaging, lightbulb <math>A</math> fails before time <math>t</math> with probability <math>F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}</math> (<math>t</math> in months). Lightbulb <math>B</math> has a probability density function for the failure time given by <math>p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.</math>

Which light bulb has the longer expected lifetime? (i.e. longer average time to failure.) Show your reasoning.
